comments.body:
For IxxxManager interface and xxxManager implementation pairs: It's a good separation for unit tests. There are no abstract base xxxManagers generally, since we don't expect that you replace those managers. Actually, this is not unique to ABP and you can find good articles on the web. That depends on your requirements and classes.
For a domain service/manager, I suggest interface+implementation since it allows you to replace it in unit tests, but in real application you will generally have a single implementation.

If you think that you have more than one implementation for an interface, we generally use this pattern:

````
interface IYourService
abstract class YourServiceBase : IYourService
class YourServiceImpl1 : YourServiceBase
class YourServiceImpl2 : YourServiceBase
````
This provides flexibility. A new implementation can directly implement IYourService or derive from YourServiceBase.
YourServiceBase generally include common base functionality, like template class pattern.

But, it's hard to say a general rule for all cases, it depends on your case.
